definition: undiscovered traitor/enemy within one's own ranks

sentences.english: By September, the gang had begun to suspect it had a mole.
sentences.chinese: 到了9月，這夥人開始懷疑出了內奸。

sentences.english: Jia small gun and others design captures the mole, turned out to be a blacksmith.
sentences.chinese: 賈小槍等人設計抓住了內奸，原來是齊鐵匠。

sentences.english: Cai Biao suddenly gun against Krishna head, said he was guilty.
sentences.chinese: 蔡彪突然用槍頂住大奎的腦袋，說他是內奸。

sentences.english: He fears that there is another traitor inside the agency.
sentences.chinese: 他擔心在辦公室裏還有另一個內奸。

sentences.english: At CTU, Jack apologizes to Nina about accusing her of being the “dirty” agent.
sentences.chinese: 在反恐組，傑克爲自己指責尼娜是內奸而向她道歉。

sentences.english: Li Shiwu doubt gold deep water is the dirty agent.
sentences.chinese: 李士武懷疑金深水就是內奸。

sentences.english: Sun Weijun ask toward him, special task force, who is the mole?
sentences.chinese: 孫維君向他問起，特別行動隊，那個內奸到底是誰？

sentences.english: To protect their mole. You getting all this, finch?
sentences.chinese: 保護他們的內奸。你都聽見了嗎，芬奇？

sentences.english: I'm a Judas, a turncoat, a quisling!
sentences.chinese: 我出賣朋友，我是內奸，是叛徒。

definition: the trick of injuring oneself to gain the enemy's confidence/CL:條|条[tiao2]
to lend sb a knife to kill sb/to get sb else to do one's dirty work/to attack using the strength of another (idiom)
to take the blame for sb else/to compensate for one's crime/to get charges dropped (by paying money etc)
villains collude together (idiom); to work hand in glove with sb (to nefarious ends)
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
old: to reap the consequences of one's words (idiom, from Mencius); modern: to go back on one's word/to blow hot and cold/to contradict oneself/inconsistent
to knock sb out with a drug/to render sb unconscious
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to play the fool (idiom)/to feign madness
to damage the country and cause suffering to the people (idiom)
